p: Rosa multiflora Thunb. is a thorny shrub, originally introduced to the U.S.A. as rootstock in 1866 from Eastern Asia [ 22][ 23] and it was later planted for erosion control and as fences and highway strips. A prolific species, a mature R. multiflora individual could produce up to one million seeds per year [ 24] and the fruits could remain viable for 20 years [ 25]. Besides seed dispersal by birds, vegetative spread is also common. Rosa multiflora is tolerant to various soils, moisture and light conditions, and can be found in open woodlands, forest edges and areas that have experienced disturbance. Rosa multiflora was introduced to Pennsylvania as rootstock during the 1930s through the 1960s [ 26].
